item.description:
But first a poem…

a midwinter's overnight muse
(a he said/she said story)

what about the huts? said she
they’re closed, said he
in the winter? said she
yes, said he
i think you’re wrong, said she
what’s new, said he

shall we go? said she
where? said he
to the HUTS!! said she
in the WINTER?? said he
YES!!! said she
THEY’RE CLOSED!!! said he
i think you’re wrong, said she
what’s new, said he

YOU should call, said she
shall we BET? said he
like candy from a baby, said she
i'm DIALING!!! said he
i'm SMILING!!! said she
hello?? said he
what's THAT?? said she
i was wrong, said he
what’s new, said she

 

Yessss!!! I know… I'm thinking, and yet I’m thinking anyway, thinking about hiking to the AMC's Lonesome Lake Hut and spending the night… thinking about hiking "in" on a Saturday morning, dropping off some of our gear at the hut, taking in a little sum’n sum’n to eat before heading out for an afternoon hike, possibly up to North Kinsman and/or over to Cannon or the Cannon Balls, and then returning to the hut for dinner, followed by a FULL MOON HIKE over and/or around the lake, games and/or conversation, or silence and sleep, only to wake on Sunday morning, eat a little more sum'n sum'n, take-in another hike, and then head back down the mountain to our cars and our homes.


 

How’s all this gonna happen?

Well, first we (meaning you) have to add your name to the "Waiting List," answer a few questions, and only after receiving our group reservation number (which I will send to you), secure 1 of 12 beds placed on hold with the AMC for the evening of January 26th, 2013… at which point you will be added to the "Going List."

We'll then meet at the Lafayette Campground-Trailhead Parking area on the morning of the 26th, hike the 1.5 miles to the hut, drop off our gear, eat, hike, eat, hike, sleep, wake, eat, hike, eat and hike some more. And should all this happen as intended, we should find ourselves back at our cars on the 27th w/ light in the sky & smiles on our faces.



About The Hike
(trail map)

On Saturday morning, we’ll begin by spending 1.5 hours, hiking 1.5 miles & climbing 1000 feet-of-up, to the lake and the hut using the Lonesome Lake Trail. Along the way we’ll bypass the Hi-Cannon Trail, as we manage a few switchbacks before reaching the Dodge Cutoff and Cascade Brook Trailheads (equally known as the eastern shore of the lake). Should there be enough ice, we’ll boogie over to the hut via a lake crossing, but should the ice be too thin, we’ll sidestep our way around the lake, by way of the Cascade Brook Trail.

After trimming our load at the hut, we’ll continue our climb. We'll follow the Fishin Jimmy Trail (a rollercoaster of a trail) to Kinsman Jct., at which point, we’ll continue our ascent by heading south on the Kinsman Ridge Trail to none other than the North Kinsman summit, and (clouds permitting) some fantastic views of Franconia Notch. Now should weather, time, trail conditions, pace and our fitness allow, we can hike to the South Kinsman summit for another batch of fantastic views, but should they not, than back to the hut we go. Hi Ho!!!

Once back at the hut, we’ll settle in for the night, fix dinner, play games (Twister anyone??) or step outside for a short hike under the very reason we're here: a FULL MOON HIKE UNDER A STAR-FILLED WINTER SKY… that is if you’re not Grumpy or Sleepy.

On Sunday morning, we’ll wake, have some breakfast, pack-up, and work our way along the western side of the lake. We’ll then pick-up the Lonesome Lake Trail, head north to the Kinsman Ridge Trail, and continue until we reach the summit of Cannon Mountain. At this point, based upon trail information, time, fitness, and our moxie, we’ll plan the return to our cars using a combination of the Hi-Cannon, Dodge Cutoff, Kinsman Ridge and Lonesome Lake Trails.

Note: We'll be paying close attention to weather and trail conditions, and should there be any adverse weather conditions, such as high winds at the summit or an approaching storm, or should trail conditions prove to be more difficult than anticipated, it may be necessary for us to avoid the summits, alter our plans, or cancel the hike altogether.

 

 

What’s most important about this hike?

Beyond the usual “risks" and "rewards" that accompany every winter hike, this outing requires an overnight reservation @ the hut, a 20 degree or lower sleeping bag* (rentable @ REI or EMS should you need), along w/ 4 meals (lunch, dinner, breakfast and lunch). All other off-season accommodations will be available @ the hut, which includes water, pots and pans, bunks and bathrooms.

* A 20 degree bag is considered absolute minimum, when used w/ fleece or thermals. This being our first time experiencing a winter overnight, it would be very prudent to bring a bag, or combination of bag & liner, equivalent to 0 or 10 degrees.

Also… very important: reservations have a "14-day" cancellation policy* in which $25 will be withheld as a cancellation fee (AMC policy); meaning… any cancellations must be made 15 days prior to the reservation in order to receive a partial refund… whereas, on the 14th day, reservations become non-refundable.

* Hence the importance of answering the questions first. I wouldn't want you to make reservations w/o your experience and gear first being vetted.


 

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST
(gear must be winter weather tested)

Cold Weather/Winter Essentials (required):
• Synthetic or Wool Wicking Underpant & Undershirt
• Mid-layer Synthetic or Wool Insulating Pant & Shirt
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket and/or Vest
• Windproof/Waterproof Shell w/hood & Pant
• Synthetic or Wool Sock Liners (wicking layer)
• Synthetic or Wool Socks (insulating layer)
• Sturdy Hiking Boots (waterproof & insulated)
• Hat & Gloves
• Balaclava
• Goggles
• Extra Insulating Layers (pantalone & top)
• Extra pair of Socks, Hat & Gloves
• Water (min. 2L) - in a wide-mouthed bottle
• Lunch/Dinner/Breakfast/Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Headlamp/Flashlight (w/ fresh lithium batteries)
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's no reason not to carry one)
• MICROspikes or more aggressive hiking crampons
• Snowshoes
• Gaiters

the Remaining Essentials:
• Medication/First Aid Supplies*
• Hand Warmers
• 0/20 Degree Sleeping Bag & Pad
• Light-weight Emergency Shelter/Bivy*
• Stove*
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellent/Toiletries
• Trekking Poles (very helpful when using snowshoes)
• Camera/Binoculars

* To Be Carried Among The Group

LET'S NOT UNDERESTIMATE ANYTHING; come prepared for the worst... cold-cold temps., snowy-snowy weather, early darkness and lots of wind.
ALSO... TAKE NOTE: the "Optional" list is significantly smaller than at any other time of year.



Directions:

From the south: Follow I-93 north to Exit 34B (Cannon Mt. Tramway Exit). Turn left, pass under the freeway, turn left and re-enter I-93 heading south. Drive approximately 2 miles south, turn right onto the Lincoln Place Campground-Trailhead Parking Exit. We'll be waiting in the parking lot. (See above for my cell number)

Google Maps: http://maps.google.com/maps?...

Coordinates: 44.143244, -71.6831

 

 

Additional Information:

AMC Lonesome Lake Hut (off-season) Accommodations:
Two bunkhouses: sleeps 48.
Coed rooms for four to seven people.
Fall, Winter and Spring self-service includes access to kitchen facilities, mattresses, pillow and bathrooms; blankets are not provided (bring your sleeping bag).
Main hut building has wood stove that will be lit by 4-4:30 p.m. during off-season.
Resident staff available with trail information and weather reports.

Lonesome Lake: 2760 feet
North Kinsman: 4293 feet
Cannon Mountain: 4100 feet

Distance from trailhead to LL Hut: approx. 1.5 miles
Elevation Gain from trailhead to LL Hut: approx. 1000+ ft

Distance from Hut to N Kinsman summit: approx. 2.5 miles
Elevation Gain from Hut to N Kinsman summit: approx. 1533 feet

Distance from Hut to Cannon summit: approx. 2.0 miles
Elevation Gain from Hut to Cannon summit: approx. 1340 feet

Exposure: None below summits; full @ summit overlooks
Difficulty: Moderate/Strenuous
Pace: Moderate

Sunrise: 7:10 a.m.
Sunset: 4:49 p.m.
Moonrise: 4:43 p.m.

Approx. High Temp: Cold
Approx. Low Temp: Really Really Cold

10-Day Weather.com Outlook:
http://www.weather.com/weather/tenday/Franconia+Notch+State+Park...

7-Day National Weather Forecast (NOAA):
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.1400395...

6-Day Mountain-Forecast.com:
http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Kinsman-Mountain...

Mt. Washington Observatory Higher Summits Forecast:
http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/summit_forecast.php

Weather & Trail Conditions (AMC):
http://www.outdoors.org/recreation/tripplanner/go/backcountry-weather.cfm

Weather & Trail Conditions (VFTT):
http://www.vftt.org/forums/forumdisplay.php?13-New-Hampshire


 

Liability Waiver

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: Follow I-93 north to Exit 34B, turn left, pass under freeway, turn left & re-enter I-93 heading south. Drive approx. 2 miles south to The Lincoln Place Campground Parking exit. We'll be in the parking lot; Cell: 860-460-1500
item.name: A Full Moon AMC Hut Midwinter's Night Sleepover
